title: Kirchhoff junction - data table for 4 resistors

overflow="scroll"><mn>6.0</mn></math> <math alttext="0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn></math> The table shows data for four resistors that are connected to a battery in a circuit. Which of the following claims about a possible series connection in the circuit is correct, and what evidence supports the claim?

choices.label: Resistors <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are the only resistors that could be connected in series. They are the only two resistors with the same current.

Resistors <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are the only resistors that could be connected in series. They are the only two resistors with the same resistance.

Resistors <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> are the only resistors that could be connected in series. They are the only two resistors with the same potential difference.
None of the resistors could be connected in series. No two resistors have the same potential difference and the same current.

content.answer: Resistors <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are the only resistors that could be connected in series. They are the only two resistors with the same current.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
